facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 64 of 1967 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 64 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 3, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Applica- tion No. 24 of 1967. A . K. Sen, S. G. Sheth and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated March 3, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Application No. 24 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 3, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Applica- tion No. 24 of 1967. A . K. Sen, S. G. Sheth and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant. S. Bindra and S. P. Nayyar, for the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant along with other persons is being tried for an offence under Sec. 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with Sec. 167 81 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, and Sec. 5 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bachawat, J. The appellant along with other persons is being tried for an offence under Sec. 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with Sec. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, and Sec. 5 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947. The offence is bailable.

The offence is bailable. The appellant was released on bail under orders of Magistrates dated May 11, 1960 and April 1, 1961. A large number of witnesses have been examined but the trial has number yet been companycluded.

facts.text: A large number of witnesses have been examined but the trial has not yet been concluded.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of witnesses have been examined but the trial has number yet been companycluded. By an order dated March 3/6, 1967, the High Court of Maharashtra, Bombay, in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction cancelled the bail orders and directed him to surrender to his bail. From this order, the present appeal has been filed by special leave.

facts.text: By an order dated March 3/6, 1967, the High Court of Maharashtra, Bombay cancelled the bail orders and directed the appellant to surrender to his bail.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated March 3/6, 1967, the High Court of Maharashtra, Bombay, in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction cancelled the bail orders and directed him to surrender to his bail. From this order, the present appeal has been filed by special leave. In Talab Haji Hussain v. Madhukar Purshottam Mondkar and another 1 , this Court held that a High Court has the inhe- rent power to cancel a bail granted to a person accused of a bailable offence where such an order is necessary to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court, and this power is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: The High Court cancelled the previous bail orders as it found that the appellant was intimidating and tampering with certain German citizens whom the prosecution intended to examine as witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court cancelled the previous bail orders, as it found that the appellant was intimidating and tampering with certain German citizens whom the prosecution intended to examine as witnesses. This finding is challenged by the appellant. Normally, it is number the practice of this Court to re-examine findings of fact in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

Art. 21 is in these terms No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. The term law in Art. 21 was the subject of an elaborate discussion in A. K. Gapalan v. The State of Madras - . Kania C.J. at pp. 111-113 said that the term law in that Article must mean the law of the State or enacted law, and number rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: the term law in that Article must mean the law of the State or enacted law, and number rules of natural justice. Fazl Ali J. who was in the minority, said at page 169 that law must include certain principles of natural justice. Patanjali Sastri J. at p. 1 99 said that law in Art. 21 means positive or State-made law. Mahajan J. at page 226 expressed numberopinion on the point. issues.text: Whether a High Court has the inherent power to cancel a bail granted to a person accused of a bailable offence where such an order is necessary to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court, and whether this power is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: In Talab Haji Hussain v. Madhukar Purshottam Mondkar and another 1 , this Court held that a High Court has the inhe- rent power to cancel a bail granted to a person accused of a bailable offence where such an order is necessary to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court, and this power is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure. On behalf of the appellant it was strenuously argued that this case was wrongly decided.

issues.text: Whether the deprivation of personal liberty by an order of the High Court cancelling bail in exercise of its inherent powers is violative of Article 21 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant argued that the inherent power of the High Court is number companyferred by any legislation or statute, and the deprivation of the personal liberty of the appellant by an order of the High Court in the exercise of its inherent -powers is violative of the companystitutional protection under Art. 21 of the Constitution. Art. 21 is in these terms No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

issues.text: Whether the inherent powers of the High Court under Sec. 561-A CrPC and confirmed by constitutional provisions qualify as 'law' or 'procedure established by law' under Article 21

anchor.surface_text: The inherent powers of the High Court preserved by Sec. 561- A of the Code of Criminal Procedure are thus vested in it by law within the meaning of Art. 21. The procedure for invoking the inherent powers is regulated by rules framed by the High Court. The power to make such rules is companyferred on the High Court by the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Sec. 561-A CrPC confers new powers or merely preserves existing inherent powers of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 561-A of the Criminal Procedure Code declared that numberhing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent power of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary  1  1958 S.C.R. 1226.  2  1950 S.C.R. 88.  3  1959 Stipp. I S.C.R.8 6. 929, to give effect to any order passed under this Code, or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was strenuously argued that this case was wrongly decided. Having heard full arguments, we find no reason for departing from our earlier decision. In the matter of admission to bail, the Code of Criminal Procedure makes a distinction between bailable and non- bailable offences.

arguments.claim: High Court has inherent power to cancel bail granted in bailable offence where necessary to secure ends of justice or prevent abuse of process, preserved by Sec. 561A CrPC

anchor.surface_text: In Talab Haji Hussain v. Madhukar Purshottam Mondkar and another 1 , this Court held that a High Court has the inherent power to cancel a bail granted to a person accused of a bailable offence where such an order is necessary to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court, and this power is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.claim: Code of Criminal Procedure distinguishes bailable and non-bailable offences; no express provision for cancellation in bailable but High Court has inherent power to arrest and commit if tampering etc.

anchor.surface_text: In the matter of admission to bail, the Code of Criminal Procedure makes a distinction between bailable and non- bailable offences. The grant of bail to a person - accused of a non-bailable offence is discretionary under Sec. 497 of the Code and the person released on bail may again be arrested and committed to custody by an order of the High Court, the Court Session and the Court granting the bail.

arguments.claim: Inherent power of High Court not conferred by legislation or statute; deprivation of liberty by its exercise violates Art. 21

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant argued that the inherent power of the High Court is not conferred by any legislation or statute, and the deprivation of the personal liberty of the appellant by an order of the High Court in the exercise of its inherent -powers is violative of the constitutional protection under Art. 21 of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ate which, as defined, includes Parliament and the Legislatures of the States. As explained by four of the learned Judges in A. K. Gapalans case 1 , t

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Law' in Art.21 means enacted or state-made law per Gopalan; HC inherent powers confirmed and preserved by statutes (CrPC 561A, GOIA s22) and Constitution (arts 225,372); analogies to legislative powers under arts 194(3),208

arguments.claim: 'Law' in Art.21 means enacted or state-made law, not principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Art. 21 is in these terms No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. The term law in Art. 21 was the subject of an elaborate discussion in A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras - . Kania C.J. at pp. 111-113 said that the term law in that Article must mean the law of the State or enacted law, and not rules of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Deprivation by Legislative Assembly for contempt follows procedure established by law per arts 194(3),208

anchor.surface_text: In Pandit M. S. M. Sharma v. Shri Sri Krishna Sinha and others 1 , this Court held that a deprivation of personal liberty of any person by a Legislative Assembly of a State in exercise of its power to punish for its contempt is according to a procedure established by law and does not contravene Art. 21.

arguments.claim: High Court inherent powers pre-existed, preserved by CrPC s.561A (declaratory), GOIA s.22, Const arts 225,372; qualify as 'law' under Art.21

anchor.surface_text: Now the question is whether the inherent power of the High Court is conferred by or has the sanction of enacted law. From its very inception the High Court has possessed and enjoyed its inherent powers including the power to prevent the abuse of the process of any Court within its jurisdiction and to secure the ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court cancelled the previous bail orders, as it found that the appellant was intimidating and tampering with certain German citizens whom the prosecution intended to examine as witnesses. This finding is challenged by the appellant.

arguments.claim: High Court's findings of fact on tampering should not be interfered with in Art.136 appeal

anchor.surface_text: This finding is challenged by the appellant. Normally, it is not the practice of this Court to re-examine findings of fact in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. Having heard full arguments, we are not inclined to interfere with the findings of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Delay in examining witnesses due to prosecution laches

anchor.surface_text: The delay in the examination of the witnesses is caused entirely by the laches of the prosecution.

holdings.text: Having heard full arguments, we find no reason for departing from our earlier decision [reaffirming that a High Court has the inherent power to cancel a bail granted to a person accused of a bailable offence where such an order is necessary to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court, and this power is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure].

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was strenuously argued that this case was wrongly decided. Having heard full arguments, we find no reason for departing from our earlier decision. In the matter of admission to bail, the Code of Criminal Procedure makes a distinction between bailable and non- bailable offences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms prior Supreme Court precedent in Talab Haji Hussain after hearing arguments; no basis to depart.

holdings.text: if at any subsequent stage of the proceedings, it is found that any person accused of a bailable offence is intimidating, bringing or tampering with the prosecution witnesses or is attempting to abscond, the High Court has the power to cause him to be arrested and to commit him to custody for such period as it thinks fit.

anchor.surface_text: The Code makes no express provision for the cancellation of a bail granted under Sec. 496. Nevertheless, if at any subsequent stage of the proceedings, it is found that any person accused of a bailable offence is intimidating, bringing or tampering with the prosecution witnesses or is attempting to abscond, the High Court has the power to cause him to be arrested and to commit him to custody for such period as it thinks fit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes bailable/non-bailable provisions in CrPC; despite no express cancellation under s.496, inherent power fills gap for exceptional circumstances like tampering.

holdings.text: For the reasons given in Talab Haji Hussains case, we hold that this inherent power of the High Court exists and is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: This jurisdiction springs from the over-riding inherent powers of the High Court and can be invoked in exceptional cases only when the High Court is satisfied that the ends of justice will be defeated unless the accused is committed to custody. For the reasons given in Talab Haji Hussains case 1 , we hold that this inherent power of the High Court exists and is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly holds existence of power based on prior precedent and CrPC s.561A preservation; applicable only in exceptional cases.

holdings.text: The inherent powers of the High Court preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure are thus vested in it by law within the meaning of Art. 21.

anchor.surface_text: The inherent powers of the High Court preserved by Sec. 561- A of the Code of Criminal Procedure are thus vested in it by law within the meaning of Art. 21. The procedure for invoking the inherent powers is regulated by rules framed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Traces historical preservation through GOIA s.22, Const arts 225 & 372; s.561A declaratory; qualifies as state-made 'law' per Gopalan.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court canceling the bail and depriving the appellant of his personal liberty is according to procedure established by law and is not violative of Art. 21.

anchor.surface_text: The rules previously in force were continued in force by Article 372 of the Constitution. The order of the High Court canceling the bail and depriving the appellant of his personal liberty is according to procedure established by law and is not violative of Art. 21.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Art.21 'law' interpretation from Gopalan; analogies to legislative powers (Pandit Sharma); inherent powers sanctioned by statutes/Constitution.

holdings.text: Sec. 561-A of the Criminal Procedure Code declared that nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent power of the High Court... it only declared that nothing in the Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the existing inherent powers of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 561-A of the Criminal Procedure Code declared that nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent power of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order passed under this Code, or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The section was inserted... it only declared that nothing in the Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the existing inherent powers of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.561A is declaratory, not conferring new powers; preserves pre-existing inherent powers.

holdings.text: Having heard full arguments, we are not inclined to interfere with the findings of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This finding is challenged by the appellant. Normally, it is not the practice of this Court to re-examine findings of fact in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. Having heard full arguments, we are not inclined to interfere with the findings of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard practice under Art.136 not to re-examine factual findings unless compelling; reviewed arguments but decline interference.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was strenuously argued that this case was wrongly decided. Having heard full arguments, we find no reason for departing from our earlier decision. In the matter of admission to bail, the Code of Criminal Procedure makes a distinction between bailable and non- bailable offences.

The order of the High Court canceling the bail and depriving the appellant of his personal liberty is according to procedure established by law and is number violative of Art. 21. The High Court cancelled the previous bail

The Code makes no express provision for the cancellation of a bail granted under Sec. 496. Nevertheless, if at any subsequent stage of the proceedings, it is found that any person accused of a bailable offence is intimidating, bringing or tampering with the prosecution witnesses or is attempting to abscond, the High Court has the power to cause him to be arrested and to commit him to custody for such period as it thinks fit.

The order of the High Court canceling the bail and depriving the appellant of his personal liberty is according to procedure established by law and is number violative of Art. 21. The High Court cancelled the previous bail
admit him to bail again. Counsel for the appellant argued that the inherent power of the High Court is number companyferred by any legislation or stat

edges.explanation: Holding declares inherent power exists and preserved by Sec. 561-A, addressing the issue of power to cancel bail

anchor.surface_text: This jurisdiction springs from the over-riding inherent powers of the High Court and can be invoked in exceptional cases only when the High Court is satisfied that the ends of justice will be defeated unless the accused is committed to custody. For the reasons given in Talab Haji Hussains case 1 , we hold that this inherent power of the High Court exists and is preserved by Sec. 561-A of the Code.

The order of the High Court canceling the bail and depriving the appellant of his personal liberty is according to procedure established by law and is number violative of Art. 21. The High Court cancelled the previous bail

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 561-A of the Criminal Procedure Code declared that nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent power of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order passed under this Code, or to prevent the abuse of process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The section was inserted... it only declared that nothing in the Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the existing inherent powers of the High Court.
